title: How to Take Apart a Track Bicycle

steps.title: Using the pedal wrench, unscrew the pedal at the edge of the crank arm.
steps.content: Using the pedal wrench, unscrew the pedal at the edge of the crank arm. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure to hold the pedal up as it gets loose, otherwise it will fall onto the floor.
steps.content: Make sure to hold the pedal up as it gets loose, otherwise it will fall onto the floor. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the dust cap and crank bolt from where the crank connects to the bottom bracket.
steps.content: Remove the dust cap and crank bolt from where the crank connects to the bottom bracket. This usually requires an allen wrench, but may vary depending on your crank brand and type. [3] X Research source Once this is removed, there will be exposed threads inside the crank arm, with the bottom bracket spindle visible inside.

steps.title: Unscrew the crank puller
steps.content: Unscrew the crank puller slightly, until the "pusher" part of the crank puller is recessed within the threaded part of the tool. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Screw the tool into the crank arm, gently at first.
steps.content: Screw the tool into the crank arm, gently at first. Make sure to screw this tool all the way in, as a great deal of pressure will be exerted on the threads when the cranks are removed. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wind the tool's handle clockwise, screwing the "pusher" part of the tool back into the bolt that is now threaded into the crank.
steps.content: Wind the tool's handle clockwise, screwing the "pusher" part of the tool back into the bolt that is now threaded into the crank. With some force, the crank will be pulled off of the bottom bracket spindle. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the wheels
steps.content: Remove the wheels by loosening the bolts attaching their hub bolts to the frame and fork (rear and front) brackets. [7] X Research source They should come right out of the brackets once loose.

steps.title: Using the chain breaker tool, pick a link and clip it into the tool.
steps.content: Using the chain breaker tool, pick a link and clip it into the tool . This is done by placing the chain link between the teeth of the chain breaker in such a way that it sits snugly.

steps.title: Using the tool like a vise, aim the arm at the small metal piece connecting the chain halves.
steps.content: Using the tool like a vise, aim the arm at the small metal piece connecting the chain halves.

steps.title: Screw in the tool until the metal piece is almost all the way out of the other side.
steps.content: Screw in the tool until the metal piece is almost all the way out of the other side. The metal slug that connects the chain link pieces should remain in just one side of the chain link, removed only just enough to let the chain break free. Be careful not to remove the piece entirely! It is extremely difficult to reinsert that piece into a chain. A good way to do this is to alternate between screwing the tool arm into the chain and removing it, checking to see if the chain has broken yet (you won't be able to tell while the chain is in the tool). Go slowly.

steps.title: Once the chain is separated, you can remove it entirely from the bike.
steps.content: Once the chain is separated, you can remove it entirely from the bike. Make sure to put it on a paper towel or other clean surface, where it will not collect dirt.

steps.title: Unscrew the brake lever from the handlebars on the underside of the lever.
steps.content: Unscrew the brake lever from the handlebars on the underside of the lever.

steps.title: Remove the brake lever from the handlebars, making sure to catch any supporting pieces that may fall.
steps.content: Remove the brake lever from the handlebars, making sure to catch any supporting pieces that may fall.

steps.title: Unscrew the bolt that is driven into the brake through the fork.
steps.content: Unscrew the bolt that is driven into the brake through the fork. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Optional:
steps.content: Optional: This is a good opportunity to change your brake pads and clean your brakes. For caliper brakes, unscrew the small bolt on each side of the caliper brake that is attached to the brake pad itself. Once the brake pads are removed, unscrew the (smaller) screw on the pad/metal assembly itself, and slide the pad out of the metal piece it is attached to. Replace the pad by sliding a fresh one in. This is a worthwhile and inexpensive repair for your bike, since brake pads are cheap and are your best friend on the road.

steps.title: Remove the bolts
steps.content: Remove the bolts from the stem that hold the handlebars tight. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Catch the faceplate piece when the last bolt is removed.
steps.content: Catch the faceplate piece when the last bolt is removed.

steps.title: Unscrew the bolt on the cap on the stem.
steps.content: Unscrew the bolt on the cap on the stem. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Unscrew the bolts on the shaft of the stem.
steps.content: Unscrew the bolts on the shaft of the stem. (This is the part where the fork can fall out.)

steps.title: Slide the stem up, off of the fork.
steps.content: Slide the stem up, off of the fork.

steps.title: Slide the spacer rings, if any, off
steps.content: Slide the spacer rings, if any, off of the fork.

steps.title: Remove the bearing ring from the cup of the frame.
steps.content: Remove the bearing ring from the cup of the frame. Place this ring on a clean paper towel or other surface. It is a good idea to clean and re-grease this with bearing grease. You can clean the ring by rubbing it with a paper towel in your hands, or with lube/cleaner. Be sure to re-grease this ring liberally; this is what rotates when you turn your handlebars to turn your bike. Ask your LBS (local bike store) for recommendations for bearing grease.

steps.title: Take careful note of the arrangement and direction of the bearing rings and supporting O-rings at this stage of the project.
steps.content: Take careful note of the arrangement and direction of the bearing rings and supporting O-rings at this stage of the project. You will need to replace them exactly as they were. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Slide the fork down
steps.content: Slide the fork down , out of the frame. Make sure not to lose the bearing ring on the fork that was resting in the lower cup of the frame.

steps.title: Slide the bearing ring and O-ring up, off the frame.
steps.content: Slide the bearing ring and O-ring up, off the frame. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Fit the bottom bracket tool
steps.content: Fit the bottom bracket tool over the bottom bracket spindle. The spindle itself is not very deep; as a result, this tool will easily come out when putting a lot of torque on the wrench to remove the bottom bracket. Be careful not to strip the splines or threads of the bottom bracket.

steps.title: The ISIS bottom bracket style has two parts, the lock ring cup and the main bottom bracket.
steps.content: The ISIS bottom bracket style has two parts, the lock ring cup and the main bottom bracket. These parts are threaded differently, and will require some trial and error to figure out which side the lock ring is on. The lock ring will be threaded normally, and will most likely unscrew somewhat easily (relative to the other side).

steps.title: Pick a side and turn counter-clockwise until the cup is removed.
steps.content: Pick a side and turn counter-clockwise until the cup is removed. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Once the cup is removed off of the spindle, turn the frame over and remove the bottom bracket itself, by turning clockwise.
steps.content: Once the cup is removed off of the spindle, turn the frame over and remove the bottom bracket itself, by turning clockwise. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Unscrew the bolt
steps.content: Unscrew the bolt at the top of the frame, where the seat post enters the frame. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Wiggle and pull the seat and post out of the frame.
steps.content: Wiggle and pull the seat and post out of the frame. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Use the lock ring tool's one-toothed side (if it also has a three-toothed side) to fit into the lock ring.
steps.content: Use the lock ring tool's one-toothed side (if it also has a three-toothed side) to fit into the lock ring. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the lock ring clockwise to remove it.
steps.content: Turn the lock ring clockwise to remove it. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Place the chain whip on the cog, on the chain part of the tool that does not hang loose.
steps.content: Place the chain whip on the cog, on the chain part of the tool that does not hang loose.

steps.title: Using your hand, wrap the loose part of the chain whips chain around the cog and apply pressure to the cog directly opposite the other chain.
steps.content: Using your hand, wrap the loose part of the chain whips chain around the cog and apply pressure to the cog directly opposite the other chain.

steps.title: Hold on tight and turn counter-clockwise to remove.
steps.content: Hold on tight and turn counter-clockwise to remove. You may have a hard time doing this; get someone else to help or get creative about how to hold the chain onto the cog. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Deflate the tube all of the way.
steps.content: Deflate the tube all of the way. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Insert the tire lever under the "clinch" part of the tire, between the rubber tire/tube and the metal rim.
steps.content: Insert the tire lever under the "clinch" part of the tire, between the rubber tire/tube and the metal rim. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Push up, lifting the lip of the tire off of the rim while simultaneously pushing down the length of the rim.
steps.content: Push up, lifting the lip of the tire off of the rim while simultaneously pushing down the length of the rim. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Once a part of the lip of the tire is over the edge of the rim, the rest will come easily.
steps.content: Once a part of the lip of the tire is over the edge of the rim, the rest will come easily. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Run the tool down the length of the wheel, removing the lip of the tire as you go.
steps.content: Run the tool down the length of the wheel, removing the lip of the tire as you go. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the valve out of the hole in the rim, and remove the tube from under the tire.
steps.content: Pull the valve out of the hole in the rim, and remove the tube from under the tire.

steps.title: At this point, one lip of the tire will be removed from the rim.
steps.content: At this point, one lip of the tire will be removed from the rim. Repeat the process for the other side.

steps.title: This is a good time to change your tube, or add a rim strip underneath the tube, if you get flat tires too frequently.
steps.content: This is a good time to change your tube, or add a rim strip underneath the tube, if you get flat tires too frequently.
